title: 110_hr3820
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commercial Motor Vehicle Advanced Safety Technology Tax Act of 2007". Congress finds that commercial motor vehicle crashes are a major concern in the United States, especially with the increasing number of trucks and their role in transporting hazardous materials. A 2004 report showed that large truck crashes are more likely to result in fatalities compared to passenger cars. In 2005, there were 5,212 deaths and 114,000 injuries from large truck-related crashes, totaling 25,533 fatalities from 2001 to 2005. These crashes not only result in human loss but also impose a significant economic cost on society. The Department of Transportation estimates that highway crashes cost society $230.6 billion a year. Investments in advanced safety technologies by vehicle suppliers and manufacturers aim to mitigate commercial motor vehicle crash scenarios. The goal is to reduce the traffic fatality rate to 1.0 per hundred million vehicle miles traveled by 2011. Accelerated deployment of these technologies can help achieve this critical goal. Congress aims to increase the deployment of advanced vehicle safety technologies on commercial motor vehicles through tax incentives to reduce injuries and fatalities on the nation's roads and highways, mitigating the societal cost of crashes. The IRS Code is amended to include a new section providing a tax credit for advanced commercial vehicle safety systems. The IRS Code is amended to include a new section providing a tax credit for commercial vehicle advanced safety systems. The credit is 50% of the cost of the system, not exceeding $1,500 per system, $3,500 per vehicle, and $350,000 per taxpayer. For tax purposes, a qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety system refers to a system enhancing safety or security, certified by the manufacturer for the specific vehicle model. The qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety system must be certified to function properly when installed on the vehicle by an authorized installer. The system's original use must begin with the taxpayer, and depreciation or amortization is allowed for the system. A qualified commercial vehicle is defined as a highway motor vehicle used for transporting persons or property in commerce. A qualified commercial vehicle is defined as a highway motor vehicle used for transporting persons or property in commerce, with specific criteria based on weight rating, seating capacity, and intended use as a school bus or intercity/local bus. The term "brake stroke monitoring system" refers to an onboard system for air-braked vehicles that uses electronic sensors to check brake adjustment and operation. The curr_chunk discusses various safety systems in vehicles, including lane departure warning, collision warning, and vehicle stability systems. These systems alert drivers of potential dangers on the road through audio, visual, or tactile notifications. Active interventions are also mentioned, such as automatically reducing the risk of rollover or directional instability. Active interventions in vehicles involve automatically reducing vehicle speed or applying brakes to align the vehicle to the correct path of travel. Controlled groups are treated as a single taxpayer, including foreign corporations. Special rules include reducing property basis by the credit amount and recapturing credits for ineligible properties. No credit allowed for property used outside the United States or by tax-exempt entities. Seller must disclose credit information to buyer for qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety systems. No credit allowed under subsection (a) for qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety systems if taxpayer elects not to apply this section. Supporting documentation required for credit approval, including system type and purchase/installation date. The section outlines requirements for claiming a credit for commercial vehicle advanced safety systems, including certification and installation details. The credit is part of the general business credit and applies to property placed in service before December 31, 2012. The text introduces amendments to the tax code related to commercial vehicle advanced safety systems. These amendments include adding a new paragraph and updating subsections in the code. The amendments made by this section apply to commercial vehicle advanced safety systems placed in service after the enactment of this Act.
